prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CGCG 049-057 - Fine resolution map in configuration C34-6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the starburst galaxy CGCG 049-057 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~38 pc at the distance of the galaxy). The accompanying coarse mapping observation with the 0.31" beam expands the maximum recoverable imaged area to 3.8", enough to cover the circumnuclear disk of the size of ~1"x2" (or 316 x 633 pc), revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2002).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to observe the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of CGCG 049-057, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) in an extended configuration (C34-6; beam size of 0.12") with a single pointing, using one baseband (of 2 GHz in width) for the line observation and three basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: We require that the observation shall have S/N > 10 for the average surface brightness of the CO(6-5) line emission in channel maps of velocity bins of 30 km/sec. We estimate a conservative line flux density per beam as follows: The VLA 1.4 GHz (Condo et al. 1990) infers a deconvolved radio size of < 2". So all the CO(6-5) flux we detected with Herschel originates largely from the central region < 2", which is roughly the same size as the circumnuclear disk of 1"x2" unveiled by Alonso-Herrero et al. (2002). We assume conservatively (a) that 70% of the total CO(6-5) flux, given in Col. (8) of Table 1, is within this nuclear disk with an area filling fraction of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 250 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Sanders et al 1991). (Note: Herschel SPIRE FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolve the CO(6-5) line.) Under these assumptions, the average surface brightness is 40.8 mJy/beam in the 0.12" beam configuration. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~26 min integration and 1.30 hr total time for this observation. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.42 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 38.
Imaging requirements: In addition to a linear resolution of slightly less than 50 pc, which is met by the 0.12" beam size proposed here, we also require good imaging quality in structures up to about 2", the major diameter of the circumnuclear star forming disk. To complement this fine resolution map, which explores angular structures up to 1.5"-2" (see Table 7.1 in the ALMA technical handbook), the accompanying short (33 min total time) observation with the 0.31" beam (or ~100 pc) increases the quality imaging area of CO(6-5) line emission up to 3.8". In the end, in additional to the high resolution (of 0.12") map of the central ~2" area, we will combine both fine and coarse resolution maps to produce a quality map of up to ~3.8" (or 1.2kpc) in diameter, with an effective resolution between 0.12" amd 0.31", as demonstrated from our ALMA Cycle-0 observations (Xu et al. 2013a).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CGCG 049-057 -- Coarse resolution map in configuration C34-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a "coarse" resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the starburst galaxy CGCG 049-057 with the 0.31" beam (corresponding to ~100 pc at the distance of the galaxy). This observation is to complement the accompanying fine-resolution map of CO(6-5) with the 0.12" beam to expand the quality imaging scale up to 3.8", enough to cover the entire circumnuclear disk of the size of ~1" x 2" (or 316 x 633 pc), revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2002).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to observe the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of CGCG 049-057, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) and in a "coarse" configuration (C34-2; beam size of 0.31'') with a single pointing, using one baseband (of 2 GHz in width) for the line observation and three other basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: The expected flux density per beam for this coarse beam size can be scaled from that estimated for the observation using the fine beam size of 0.12" (see the Technical Justification session of the science goal of the fine resolution mapping observation of CGCG 049-057). This results in an average surafce brightness of 27.2 mJy/beam for the 0.31" beam size, over the targeted circumnuclear disk of 1"x2" (Alonso-Herrero et al 2002), where most of the CO(6-5) line emission comes from. ALMA OT shows that this coarse resolution observation is very much dominated by calibration and overhead times. So we just asked for detecting a CO(6-5) flux density of 10 mJy/beam at S/N = 10 in channel maps of velocity bins of 30 km/sec. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~ 4 min on-target integration and a total time of ~33 min for the observation. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 1.1 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 99.
Imaging requirements: With the expected maximum recoverable scale of 3.8", this coarse observation is to complement the fine-resolution observation of the same target with the 0.12" beam, in order to secure good imaging quality in structures covering the entire circumnuclear disk of about 2" in diameter, revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2002). In the end, in additional to the high-resolution (of 0.12") map of the central ~2" area, we will combine both maps to produce a quality map of up to ~3.8" (or 1.2 kpc) in diameter, with an effective angular resolution between 0.12" and 0.31" as demonstrated from our ALMA cycle-0 observations (Xu et al. 2013a).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 5179 --fine resolution map in ALMA configuration C34-6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and 450 micron dust continuum over the central ~2" area in the nuclear region of the starburst galaxy IC 5179 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~30 pc at the distance of the galaxy). This enables us to detail gas distribution within the compact nuclear core of < 1", revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to map the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of IC 5179, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) in an extended configuration (C34-6; beam size of 0.12'') with a single pointing, using one baseband (of 2 GHz in width) for the line observation and three other basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: We require that the observation shall have S/N >10 for the average surface brightness of the CO(6-5) emission in channel maps of velocity bins of 30 km/s. We estimate a conservative line flux density per beam as follows: The Spitzer 8 um image shows that about 65% of the 8 um flux is within the HST field of view (19.5"x19.5") of the Paschen-alpha line emission observation of Alonso-Herrero et al. (2006). This means that more than 65% of the Herschel detected CO(6-5) flux should originate from within this HST field of view, within which about 50% of the Paschen-alpha flux is from the central compact core of size < 1" (see Alonso-Herrero et al 2006). On the other hand, the less dust extinction-affected, high angular resolution (0.4") image at 8 micron (Diaz-Santo et al. 2008) suggests that the CO(6-5) flux might be significantly more concentrated in the nuclear core. As a result, it is conservative to assume that 50% of the Hersche-detected CO(6-5) flux, given in Col. (8) of Table 1, is from this compact nuclear core of 1" in diameter. We assume further (a) an area filling factor of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 250 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Garay et al. 1993). (Note: the Herschel FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolve the line.) Under these assumptions, the average surface brightness is 27.8 mJy/beam for the 0.12" beam. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~42 min on-target integration and 1.84 hr total time for this observation. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.3 mJy/beam. This results in S/N > 61.
Imaging requriements: The observation has a maximum recoverable scale of ~2" (cf. Table 7.1 in the ALMA Technical Handbook), which is a factor of 2 larger than the size of the compact nuclear core targeted here. We therefore do not ask for another "coarse" observation on this target.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 5135 --fine resolution map in ALMA configuration C34-6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 5135 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~35 pc at the distance of the galaxy) in Band 9. The accompanying coarse mapping observation with the 0.31" beam shall expand the maximum recoverable scale to 3.8", enough to cover the circumnuclear disk of the size of ~2" x 2.5" (or 591 x 739 pc), revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to observe the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of NGC 5135, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) in an extended configuration (C34-6; beam size of $0.12''$) with a single pointing. We use one baseband (of 2 GHz in width) for the line observation and three other basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: We require that the observation shall have S/N > 10 for the average surface brightness of the CO J=6-5 emission in channel maps of velocity bins of 15 km/sec. We estimate a conservative line flux density per beam as follows: The VLA 1.4 GHz (Condo et al. 1996) infers a size of ~6"x6". So all the CO(6-5) flux we detected with Herschel shall originate mostly from within the HST field of view (19.5"x19.5") of the Paschen-alpha line observation of Alonso-Herrero et al (2006), in which they show that most of Paschen-alpha emission is limited to the circumnuclear disk/ring of ~ 2"x2.5". This is confirmed by the high resolution (0.4") 8 micron image of Diaz-Santos et al (2008). We therefore assume conservatively (a) that 70% of the total CO(6-5) flux, given in Col. (8) of Table 1, is within this nuclear disk with an area filling fraction of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 150 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Gao & Solomom 2004). (Note: The Herschel FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolved the line.) Under these assumptions, the average surface brightness is 57.7 mJy/beam in the 0.12" beam configuration. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~20 min integration and 1.14 hr total time for this observation. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.43 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 23.
Imaging requirements: In addition to a linear resolution of slightly less than 50 pc, which is met by the 0.12'' beam size proposed here, we also require good imaging quality in structures slightly beyond a scale of 2.5", the major diameter of the circumnuclear star forming disk, revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006). To complement this fine resolution map, which explores angular structures up to ~2" (see Table 7.1 in the ALMA Technical Handbook), the accompanying short (39 min total time) observation with the 0.31" beam (or ~100 pc) increases the quality imaging area of the CO(6-5) line emission up to 3.8". In the end, in additional to the high resolution (of 0.12") map of the central ~2" area, we shall also combine both observations to produce a map of up to ~3.8" (or 1.12kpc) in diameter with an effective resolution between 0.12" and 0.31" as demonstrated from our ALMA Cycle-0 observations (Xu et al. 2013a).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 5135 - Coarse resolution map in C34-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a "coarse" resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the Sy2 galaxy NGC 5135 with the 0.31" beam (corresponding to ~92 pc at the distance of the galaxy). This observation is to complement the accompanying fine resolution map of CO(6-5) with the 0.12" beam (with maximum recoverable scale of ~2") to expand the quality imaging scale up to 3.8", enough to cover the entire circumnuclear disk of the size of ~2" x 2.5" (or 591 x 739 pc), revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to observe the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of the galaxy NGC 5135, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) and in a "coarse" configuration (C34-2; beam size of 0.31'') with a single pointing, using one baseband (of width = 2 GHz) for the line observation and three other basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: The expected flux density per beam for this coarse beam size can be scaled from that estimated for the observation using the fine beam size of 0.12" (see the Technical Justification session of the science goal of the fine resolution mapping observation of NGC 5135). This results in an average 38.3 mJy/beam for the 0.31" beam size, over the circumnuclear disk of 2"x2.5" (Alonso-Herrero et al 2006), where most of the detected CO(6-5) line emission comes from. ALMA OT shows that this coarse resolution observation is very much dominated by calibration and overhead times. So we just asked for detecting a CO(6-5) flux density of 10 mJy/beam at S/N = 10 in channel maps of velocity bins of 15 km/sec. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~ 6 min on-target integration and a total time of ~39 min. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.9 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 400.
Imaging requirements: With the expected maximum recoverable scale of 3.8", this coarse observation is to complement the fine-resolution observation of the same target with the 0.12" beam, in order to secure good imaging quality in structures slight larger than 2.5", the major diameter of the circumnuclear star forming disk, revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006). In the end, in additional to the high resolution (of 0.12") map of the central ~2" area, we will combine both fine and coarse resolution observations to produce a map of up to ~3.8" (or 1.12 kpc) in diameter, with an effective angular resolution between 0.12" and 0.31" as demonstrated from our ALMA cycle-0 observations (Xu et al. 2013a).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 7130 --fine resolution map in C34-6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum over the central ~2" area in the nuclear region of the Seyfert 1.9 galaxy NGC 7130 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~42 pc at the distance of the galaxy). This allows for detailed study of the distribution of dense and warm molecular gas in and around the compact unclear core of < 1", revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (0.1"-0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Instrument Setup: We propose to observe the CO J=6-5 line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum emission in the nuclear region of NGC 7130, using the Band 9 of ALMA in the TDM mode (smoothed velocity resolution: 13 km/sec) and in an extended configuration (C34-6; beam size of 0.12'') with a single pointing, using one baseband (of 2 GHz in width) for the line observation and three other basebands for the continuum observation.
Sensitivity requirements: We require that the observation shall have S/N >10 for the average surface brightness of the CO(6-5) emission in channel maps of velocity bins of 15 km/s. We estimate a conservative line flux density per beam as follows: The VLA 1.4 GHz map infers a size of 7"x6" (Condon et al. 1996). This is smaller than the HST field of view (19.5"x19.5") of the Paschen-alpha line emission observation of Alonso-Herrero et al. (2006). This means that almost all the Herschel detected CO(6-5) flux originates from within this HST field of view, within which about 50% of the Paschen-alpha flux is from the central core of < 1" (see Alonso-Herrero et al 2006). On the other hand, the less dust extinction-affected, high angular resolution (0.4") image at 8 micron (Diaz-Santo et al. 2008) suggests that the CO(6-5) flux might be more concentrated in the nuclear core. As a result, it is quite conservative to assume that 50% of the Hersche-detected CO(6-5) flux, in Col. (8) of Table 1, is from the compact nuclear core of 1" in diameter. We assume further (a) an area filling factor of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 150 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Albrecht et al. 2007). (Note: the Herschel FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolve the line.) Under these assumptions, the average surface brightness is 118.6 mJy/beam for the 0.12" beam. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~5 min on-target integration and 33.5 min total time for this observation. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.88 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 20.
Imaging requriements: The observation has a maximum recoverable scale of ~2" (cf. Table 7.1 in the ALMA Technical Handbook), which is a factor of 2 larger than the size of the nuclear compact core targeted here.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA mapping in Band-9 at 0.12"/beam of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 um dust continuum in the nuclei of 4 luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs). The data will reveal, for the first time, nuclear dense molecular gas distribution at resolutions < 50 pc, characteristic size of GMCs. Our targets include 2 starbursts and 2 AGNs, and represent two most common nuclear configurations in LIRGs: two targets with a compact nuclear core of < 1" (< 300 pc) and two with a circumnuclear disk of 2" to 2.5" in diameter (500 to 1000 pc). For the latter two targets, we also request quick ALMA observations of CO(6-5) at 0.31"/beam to recover structures over the entire nuclear disk. Our proposal expands our ALMA sample from two LIRGs observed in Cycle-0 to 4 more that represent more typical LIRGs. The ALMA results are crucial in determining physical gas/dust conditions in different nuclear configurations, spatial correlation between CO(6-5) and Pa-alpha emissions, the role AGN plays in gas heating and feedback, and if nuclear dense molecular gas remains in discrete GMCs or is compressed into spatially continuous molecular gas over scales much larger than 50 pc.
